Next to the slasher films of the 1970s and 80s, ones about the walking dead were probably the second most popular horror sub-genre in modern cinema. The success of George A. Romero’s 1968 Night of the Living Dead spawned remakes, sequels and even its own franchise. Even director John Carpenter’s famous ‘truck incident’ can be boiled down to a case of the wrong zombie movie playing on the TV he tried to watch.

Reading through these comments, I see a remarkable socio-cultural clash theme emerging between the US and... the Dutch! The US — a land where anyone from anywhere can pick themselves up, put down roots, start anew, thrive, succeed—in other words, a land of immigrants and opportunity. And one where the taxpayers pay for everything.

The Dutch — a place that values privileged educations, subsidizes foreign workers into top positions

River Queen attempts to pack a complicated, sweeping, historical narrative into just under two hours. There are some breathtaking battle scenes and the Wanganui scenery is beautiful, well suited to the lush tragedies of love and war.

The Bone Snatcher is about a group miners who go on a search for a missing crew of miners in the Namib Desert. When the find them, the crew are found in an area with spikes with feeding tubes going all over the place and several skeletons and bodies, including two of the members of the original crew of the vehicle who found this place. Snow White is in my opinion a bad movie on an artistic point of view. The plot is pretty much foreseeable, the characters are stereotypes, the editing too. The movie is pale by comparison to My Life as a Zucchini.
My Life as a Zucchini is a movie with beautiful drawings by a pretty traditional plot. Brother's relationship between siblings, hate between siblings are the main theme here. But this movie has found a way to revisit the story and provides a different look
